name: February Meetup
description:
Greetings all the fantastic Aussie Android developers,
As you know, we have arranged for the first Android Australia meetup in Melbourne to go ahead on 23 February. 
Android Australia User Group is at a critical transformation stage. Nick did a fabulous job of founding this group and nurturing it through its initial stages, and has now handed over the group's administrative tasks to James and I. Let me stress again that we only see ourselves as administrators of the group, and would like Android Australia to become a truly independent, organic and community-driven user group. 

Android is at an amazing moment and we all know that it's going to explode in 2011 in Australia. With that, demand for Android developers will also grow by the day. As a community, we can only become stronger if we share our knowledge and resources, and help each other out with things we have discovered in true open source tradition. This means all members of the community who care about this group and its future should put their hands up to become more involved with it. 

James and I have had some preliminary discussions. We would like Android Australia to hold regular workshops and hackathons. We also think we could benefit from quarterly presentations and talks, and of course Q&A sessions. We would like to interact more often with other mobile development groups and also with other open source projects at large. Perhaps we can sometimes take part in their gatherings with a talk about Android, and sometimes invite them to speak at our events. Ideally, we would also like to hold one big annual conference, in the style of Android Pro-Am that Nick organised so successfully last November (I still need to ask him what "Pro-Am" stands for!) We also hope that Android Australia could eventually become a home for start-ups, entrepreneurs, and everyone who thinks they've got a brilliant idea and would like to have a go. 
To shell out all these details, share our vision for the future of the group and explore other ideas, we are inviting all committed members to join us on Wednesday, February 23 at 6:00 PM at 243 Collins Street in Melbourne. jTribe is again graciously sponsoring the event and providing amenities. We couldn't do this without them. 
Also feel free to bring your laptops with the Android SDK/NDK installed. We would be hosting the first workshop in a very informal manner, where everyone can just demonstrate what they are working on, share some ideas and learn from each other. 
While everyone is welcome, we would like to keep this first workshop small, so that we can actually make decisions on the future of the group. Please make sure you come if you see yourself as someone who is going to stick around and be active and involved in the group. 
Pizza and beer will be provided, courtesy of our host jTribe. 
If you would like to join us, please go to </a><a href="http://www.meetup.com/Android-Australia-User-Group/" target="_blank">http://www.meetup.com/Android-Australia-User-Group/ to register your interest. We need to have an idea of how many people are coming to arrange for food and drinks.
Feedback and comments are welcome, as always. 
Cheers
-- 
Aryan

name: Android Australia User Group: June Melbourne Hack Day
description:
Sometimes working on those awesome Android projects by yourself can be a little boring - perhaps its time to get out and hack with some like-minded people?

The Android Australia User Group proudly brings you our first hack day in mid June at OpenHub.

Scheduled for the 11th of June 2011 - starting at midday 12PM to 6PM.

The idea is to keep the developer vibe alive in-between our monthly meetup sessions, which are presentation driven, with a co-working style meetup.

This is where the real magic happens, feel free to bring down your laptop and hack at your own projects, or maybe work on a new project with new people. The day is completely up to you.

This is also a great opportunity for beginners to come in and learn the ropes from the pros and semi-pros.

Due to venue capacity for tables/chairs - we can only have up to 15 members for this event. RSVP is mandatory!

Please note: food and drinks are BYO - depending on how the group feels, we can all head off for a group dinner after we pack up.

name: Android Australia User Group: June Melbourne Meetup
description:
Hi Everyone,

Welcome to the our June Meetup. This month's main topic is "Honeycomb Development".

This month we have a guest speaker from Google, developer advocate Tony Chan, who will be presenting on honeycomb development to the AAUG community. Hopefully this will get you all started on developing amazing applications for tablets.

Assoc. Professor Shonali Krishnaswamy will present the Open Mobile Miner (OMM) toolkit and the team of researchers/developers from the Centre for Distributed Systems and Software Engineering, Monash University.
This talk will outline the system architecture of OMM and demonstrate our software tool for real-time mobile data analysis. The OMM system is operational on the Google Android and Symbian platforms.

 

Please note that RSVP is mandatory.

name: Special Event - Amazon Cloud Drive [Melb]

venue.name: Regus Office, Rialto South Tower, Level 27

description:
Amazon.com are visiting Melbourne in October (they are hiring !) and wanted to give a tech-talk to interested Melbourne developers. Hear first hand what Amazon are doing and what it might be like to work there. We are delighted to assist them with event logistics. Numbers are limited so get in quick for this unique opportunity. Hope you can come along  -- Leon Gouletsas

 

Amazon Cloud Drive Tech-Talk (Melbourne)

In March 2011, Amazon launched some of its most disruptive and revolutionary products – Amazon Cloud Drive and Cloud Player. This talk will outline the motivations, customer experience, architecture, scalability, and security of Amazon first consumer cloud product offering. Come understand Amazon culture of technology and innovation and see how our ideas become concrete products for our customers.

Presenter: Piragash Velummylum

Piragash Velummylum is a technology leader in digital media and cloud computing at Amazon.com, where he pitched and founded Amazon Cloud Drive, pioneered new business initiatives, led teams, mentored engineers, authored over 20 patents and won Amazon Hack Day. He is now leading a brand new initiative at Amazon and disrupting the digital media and cloud computing space once again.

 

Venue & Time: 

6pm, Sunday October 16th

Regus Office, Rialto South Tower, Level 27 @ 525 Collins Street Melbourne

name: Google - Android Developer Lab
description:
Google has announced they are running Android Developer Lab sessions. This has no relation with the Android Australia User Group - however we are promoting it because it aligns with our User Group's purpose :)

Note: Registration for this event is via the dedicated ADL sites - not via AAUG

Details below are from their website: https://sites.google.com/site/androiddeveloperlabs/melbourne

</a> Date: 31st January 2011
Location: TBA, Melbourne
Details: In this ADL, we'll guide you through best practices to build high-quality phone and tablet apps for Android.  Specifically, we will cover:

Latest in Android technologies Market cloud services Designing polished and immersive user experiences Building rich apps for phones and tablets with a single code base Please note, this event is for experienced Android developers with existing applications in Android Market.  In order to process your registration, we require you to include the package name of your best application currently published in Android Market.  If you have not yet published an app, you can still register but preference will be given to those who have already published apps.
Pre-requisites:

Laptop with the Eclipse & Android SDK (API 15) installed and configured. Android device for debugging - could be a phone or tablet, both would be preferable. Solid understanding of Android fundamentals - activities, layouts, app life cycle, etc.
Seating is limited, not all registrants will be confirmed attendees.  Confirmation emails will be delivered up to 48 hours before the event.
<a href="https://docs.google.com/a/google.com/spreadsheet/viewform?formkey=dHVsQmJoYTE1Rl9BLU8zR2xuV3BiMWc6MA" target="_blank">Click to register

name: AAUG: October Meetup
description:
Agenda

6:00PM - Start (Pizza and drinks)

6:15PM -  Nick Marfleet from Blocks Global

How it took 2.5 years to put HTML content on a tablet     - A journey into the depths of Android

All we wanted to do was play HTML content on a tablet.  How hard can it be?  I’ve got a 14yo nephew who can do that in an hour I hear you shout!  Well this simple starting point has led us on a near 3 year journey of discovery including completely changing our company (We started out as a digital Agency, now we’re embedded Android Specialists) and have learnt far more about Android than we ever knew we wanted to know.I’ll share the journey, and touch on some high level Android Internals on the way through.

6:45PM  - Scott Barnett from Swinburne University

RAPPT - A rapid prototyping tool for native Android Apps

name: AAUG: 2014 Christmas Meetup/Party
description:
Come celebrate a joint meetup christmas party with Android Australia user Group (Melbourne) & friends!

We're joining forces with a number of meetups: 
- Melbourne Developer Meetup [30 Spots] 
- Infrastructure Coders [40 Spots] 
- Android Australia User Group Melbourne [40 Spots] 
- Melbourne Tessel Enthusiasts [5 Spots]

There will be great prizes on offer. Food and drinks will be provided by our sponsor Odecee, who have also organised a great venue for us, with plenty of capacity for a large group and a Grand Prix training simulator for your entertainment!

We'll be showcasing what each meetup is all about, with the chance to get to know a little more about your fellow meetup organisers and members.

Most importantly we're wanting to wind down and reflect on a spectacular 12 Months with good (and a little geeky) company.

Note: The ticket price for this event is $10 & Your money will go towards prizes on the night.

name: Google IO Extended Lunch + Hack
description:
Google IO kicks off early this Friday (May 29th) morning and that always means an opportunity to explore new APIs, devices and services from Google.

We are having a lunch time viewing of the Google IO Keynote highlights (the thought of a 2:30am is tough). For those who can stay on, we want to start hacking on any of the new tech goodies Google announce. 

We also have an announcement as a group, and hopefully (if it arrives in time) some swag!

Kickoff is at 12pm on Friday, with lunch provided (thanks Odecee!) and Google IO Keynote highlights covered until 1pm. 

Then from 1pm - 5pm, for those who can stay on, let's start hacking together on what gets announced. 

All will be run from upstairs at the Odecee office.

Please RSVP so we know what to cater for lunch. Thanks!

name: September - Google Developer Group Meetup
description:
PLEASE NOTE: We are now a Google Developer Group, so are transitioning off of meetup.com and onto Google+. Please follow our G+ group and accept the G+ event invitation for this event so that Google can keep better track of our numbers, which in turn makes it more likely that they will send us more speakers! 

OK, now here's the actual event info:

GDG Melbourne is locked-in for September!

This month, we’re excited to have two presenters from the upcoming YOW! Connected conference previewing their talks, both of which relate to Google technologies:

- “Was If Frag-ment To Be?” by Luke Sleeman. The Fragment API forms one of the core components Google has provided to build Android apps. Despite the key role it is meant to play, many people find Fragments hard to use, prone to bugs and frustrating. We will pose the question - do we actually need Fragments? Are they worth the trouble?

- “Progressive Web Apps: What has the web ever done for us?” by Gareth Jones. Progressive Web Apps (PWAs) are an initiative being driven by Google that bring us a step closer to not needing to develop native mobile apps. This talk will give developers an insight into the problems that PWAs can solve, how you go about building them, and some ways to decide if they are right for your project.

Note that these won’t be the full versions of the YOW! Connected presentations (you’ll have to go to the conference for those) but should give you a taste of what they’re all about. For more information about YOW! Connected, see http://connected.yowconference.com.au

Doors open for drinks at 6pm, and talks will kickoff at 6:30pm. There'll also be pizza, and when the talks finish up (around 7:30pm) there'll be more time for drinks and networking. Look forward to seeing you then!﻿
how_to_find_us: We're in the AMP building on the corner of Bourke and King St. Come into the ground floor foyer, grab a lift up to level 30 and there'll be somebody at the door!

description:
PLEASE NOTE: We are now a Google Developer Group, so are transitioning off of meetup.com and onto Google+. OK, now here's the actual event info:

GDG Melbourne is out of the gates for October! This month, our presentations will be:

- "Polished Droids: Bringing Android Apps to Chromebooks": Maks Lin will follow up on his introductory talk from earlier in the year, this time with an account of his more recent experience getting a popular Android open-source app to work on Chromebooks. This talk will be based on his recent presentation at YOW! Connected.

- "Google Guava": Suken Shah will give an overview of Google's 'Guava' library, a set of Java utilities that helps with collections, functional types, caching, concurrency and more. He’ll talk about how it helps your code become cleaner and more optimised, and why he thinks it's the 'One utility library to rule them all'!

Doors open for drinks at 6pm, and talks will kickoff at 6:30pm. There'll also be pizza, and when the talks finish up (around 7:30pm) there'll be more time for drinks and networking. Look forward to seeing you then!﻿

name: November - Google Developer Group Meetup
description:
GDG Melbourne is blasting into November! This month, our presentations will be:

- “How to achieve 80% code coverage on Android” by Jarod Robbins from Itty Bitty Apps. Jarrod will talk about his experiences working on a client app that had an 80% code coverage requirement, and argue that testing mobile apps doesn't have to be hard. This talk will provide tips on how to structure your code to make it easily testable, as well as outline the benefits of adopting testing in your apps - even if it's just a little bit. Finally, Jarod will cover how they were able to use a Sinatra-based stub server to help with their UI testing.

- "Lessons learnt from rebuilding the Coles app" by Patrick Richards and Dan Parkinson from Domestic Cat. Over the past 18 months Domestic Cat have rebuilt the Coles 3.0 app for Android and iOS, including adding a slick new interface. They will present some of the key lessons learnt from building and testing an app installed by over 500,000 people.

Doors open for drinks at 6pm, and talks will kickoff at 6:30pm. There'll also be pizza, and when the talks finish up (around 7:30pm) there'll be more time for drinks and networking. Look forward to seeing you then!﻿

name: January - Google Developer Group Meetup
description:
GDG Melbourne is back and better than ever in 2017! This month, our presentations will be:

- “ADB GUI Tool” by Evgeni Shafran from REA group. Evgeni will talk about the ADB debugger GUI tool that he as created in his free time. Evgeni plans to make the tool open source. 

- "Butterknife" by Saloni Sharma. Butterknife is an injection library for Android which allows you to annotate the inflation of your views and OnClickListeners so that you can get back to writing the code that really matters. Butter Knife enables focus on logic instead of glue code and reduces development time by reducing redundant coding.

name: February - Google Developer Group Meetup
description:
Get ready for GDG Melbourne in February! This month, our two presentations will be:

- “Tinkering with the Google Cloud Vision API on a RaspberryPi, and processing images of your favourite pets.” by Graham Polley from Shine Solutions. Graham is a Google Developer Expert for the Google Cloud Platform. He will be talking about his recent side project where he tested the Google Cloud Vision API on a RaspberryPi. Google’s Cloud Vision API is one of their latest machine learning technologies to be exposed as a cloud service to developers. Simply make a REST call, and you can leverage the power of Google’s incredibly sophisticated machine learning algorithms, without ever needing to know how it works under the hood. 

- "The Ultimate Ninja of Kotlin Libraries" by Kai Koenig from Ventego Creative in Wellington, New Zealand. Kai will be delivering a remote presentation on Kotlin Libraries. Kotlin is a new language for the JVM that aims to be a "better Java". Made in-house by Jetbrains, the company behind IntelliJ IDEA and also Android Studio, it's been in development for more than 5 years. Just a few weeks ago the final version of Kotlin 1.0 saw the light of day.

Doors open for drinks at 6pm, and talks will kickoff at 6:30pm. There'll also be pizza, and when the talks finish up (around 7:30pm) there'll be more time for drinks and networking. Look forward to seeing you then!﻿

name: Google Developers Melbourne - March - Design & Cool AI
description:
Welcome to Google Developers Melbourne March Meetup. This month we have design, cool AI and Android O!

Lightning talk - What's new in Android O - Dylan Graham

1st talk - An Introduction to Google Design Sprints - Peter Collins

2nd talk - Cool AI stuff from Japan! - Luke Sleeman

Whats new in Android O

Android O - the next version of Android has just had its first preview release.  Dylan Graham will give us a quick overview of what's new and which features developers should keep their eyes on!

An Introduction to Google Design Sprints

Come along and learn all about Google design sprints. We'll cover an overview of what they are and how they can be used to rapidly identify great product ideas by putting end-users at the heart of the process. I'll give you hints and tips on how to run them, what they are and aren't used for and how as developers you can play a critical part in this early part of product inception.

Cool AI stuff from Japan!

Luke recently attended a ML experts meeting in Singapore. There were quite a few attendees from Japan, who had some really cool stuff to present. We will get a quick rundown of some of the fun projects they have been working on: Cucumber recognition, A chicken nugget sorting robot, AI generated pop stars, recognising car features for an auction website, and car packing space recognition by drone! This will be a pretty informal presentation where we will just run through a number of youtube videos explaining what they are about.

Doors open for drinks at 6pm, and talks will kickoff at 6:30pm. There'll also be pizza, and when the talks finish up (around 7:30pm) there'll be more time for drinks and networking. Look forward to seeing you then!﻿

name: Google Developers Melbourne - April - "Testing 123..." and lightning talks
description:
Welcome to Google Developers Melbourne April Meetup.  This month we have Testing and Lightning Talks!

Lightning Talks - Dylan Graham, Chris Jewell and Luke Simpson

2nd Talk - "Testing 123 ..." - Kelly Wason

"Testing 123 ..."

We've all done it... installed an app and said "seriously, has anyone tested this thing?" Good question, has the app been tested? If so, by whom and did they know what to look for when they did.
There are a number of techniques that can be applied by developers or, better yet, a dedicated tester to help ensure that quality apps are being built.
Kelly will outline some of these techniques, why they should be applied, by whom, and how.

Lightning Talks

For April we are going to try a slightly different format - We going to have a number of lightning talks.  The 3 Lightning talks will be:

Something about Gradle - Dylan Graham

The Gradle build tool is improving all the time. Find out what's new and upcoming for Android developers<a href="https://github.com/pushtorefresh/storio"></a>


Google I/O Preview - Luke Simpson

The schedule is out and Google really, really, really wants us to use Firebase. Luke breaks down the content and release rumours for next month’s I/O conference.


My First Andrdoid app - Chris Jewell

Chris dishes up all the goss on the yackandandah folk festival app build.

Doors open for drinks at 6pm, and talks will kickoff at 6:30pm. There'll also be pizza, and when the talks finish up (around 7:30pm) there'll be more time for drinks and networking. Look forward to seeing you then!﻿

name: I/O Extended 2017 Melbourne
description:
GDG Melbourne will be hosting a I/O Extended event to recap all of the major announcements from Google I/O and talk about what's new in the Google world.  I/O is Google's annual developer conference, where new products and API’s are announced and technology showcased.  I/O also features a large number of technical in sessions focused on building products with Google's technologies such as Android, Google Cloud and Tensorflow.

I/O can be a busy time with a bewildering array of product announcements, new technologies and updates to make sense of.  GDG Melbourne will bring together expert developers to help you cut through the hype and understand what's important and what's not.  We will be having presentations focused on what's new in Android, Firebase, IOT and ML and a recap of the ‘IO experience’ by an I/O attendee.  

The I/O Experience - Brendan Wreford

Brendan will talk about his experience attending IO.  Find out what it was like to be there ‘on the ground’ during the keynote, hear about the best and worst technical presentations and what the after-parties were like!  

Android: What’s new - Andrew Kelly 

Andrew Kelly will cover all the new Android related announcements; Android O (including fonts, scaling text views, etc) the big Kotlin announcement, new support library features, and new developer tools!

Andrew Kelly is a Freelance Android developer based in Sydney, he's worked on apps for eBay, Commonwealth Bank, BIG W and the Sydney Opera House. Andrew is also a Google Developer Expert for Android and one of the organisers of the Google Developer Group in Sydney.  Andrew is being flown in from Sydney, especially for the event!

Firebase, IOT and ML: What’s New  - Daniel Bradby

I/O 2017 promises to have a heavy focus on firebase, IOT and machine learning. REA Technical Lead Daniel Bradby will discuss some of the new announcements and technologies around firebase, IOT and Machine Learning.

Doors open for drinks at 6pm, and talks will kickoff at 6:30pm. There’ll also be pizza, and when the talks finish up there’ll be more time for drinks, networking and discussion.

We also have free T-shirts for our attendees.  We have both mens and womens T's in a variety of sizes.  The T-shirts will be given away on a first come, first served basis, so if you want to get your exact size, make sure you arrive on time!

name: Google Developers Melbourne - June - "MVVM" and lightning talks
description:
Welcome to Google Developers Melbourne June Meetup.  This month we have MVVM and Lightning Talks!

Lightning Talks - "Stackdriver", "Android View State Storing, and it's Gotcha!" and "Standardising colour on Android"

2nd Talk - "MVVM" - Clinton Rocksmith

"MVVM"

MVVM (Model-View-ViewModel) is here to stay, would you like to know how to implement it?  Drawing on nearly 10 years of working with this architectural style, Clinton Rocksmith will demonstrate the hard learned lessons and common pitfalls that can happen implementing it.  The talk will cover the history and origins of MVVM and what problems it tries to solve, best-practices to use when implementing it and where should the code go to ensure that your application is testable and the state of your application can be confirmed. Then by looking at the latest Architectural SDK’s released at Google I/O 2017, Clinton will outline what benefits these bring to the troubles of implementing MVVM on Android and how these can be used to remove further risks of memory leaks.

Lightning Talks

Stackdriver - Suken Shah

Android View State Storing, and it's Gotcha! - Elisha

Standardising colour on Android - Benjamin Pope

Doors open for drinks at 6pm, and talks will kickoff at 6:30pm. There'll also be pizza, and when the talks finish up (around 7:30pm) there'll be more time for drinks and networking. Look forward to seeing you then!﻿

description:
Welcome to Google Developers Melbourne, July Meetup.

This month we have Google Home, Lightning Talks and a Door Prize!

Lightning Talks:   Video intelligence by Graham Polley and Stetho: using DevTools for native app debugging by Maksim Lin.

🎉 We also have a  Door prize 🎉 

A Yow Connected Ticket, will be given away by Katie Osbourne from Hays Digital Tech

Main talk

Developing an Android instant app for REA - Antony Kuzmicich, Technical Product Manager, REA Group 

Recently realestate.com.au worked with Google to launch an Android Instant App to provide users a native experience for viewing property details without the need to install an app. In this lightning talk Antony will walk us through the user experience, what was required technically to create their Instant App, and what they've learnt from the initiative. 

Lightning Talks

Graham Polley - Video intelligence

Graham will talk us through googles cloud video intelligence and how developers can use it https://cloud.google.com/video-intelligence/

Maksim Lin - Stetho: using DevTools for native app debugging

Stetho is a sophisticated debug bridge for Android applications.  Maksim will show how it may be used to make the lives of Android developers easier!

Doors open for drinks at 6pm, and talks will kickoff at 6:30pm. There'll also be pizza, and when the talks finish up (around 7:30pm) there'll be more time for drinks and networking. Look forward to seeing you then!﻿

description:
Welcome to Google Developers Melbourne, August Meetup.

This month we have Scaling Mobile Engineering and Lightning Talks!

Lightning Talks: 

Smart Lock - Mark Ng

Getting started with the Google Home - Darren Cibis

Main talk

Scaling Mobile Engineering Teams - Lessons learnt @ iflix and Etsy

Deniz Veli, Platforms Lead at iflix

Growing your mobile engineering team sustainably while also delivering quality features in your product is a difficult challenge. Adding more engineers onto a project does introduce new problems. How do your development, testing and delivery processes evolve as a team grows? Deniz Veli will share advice and lessons learnt from working on small, medium and large scale mobile engineering teams, including scaling the mobile teams at Etsy and iflix.

Doors open for drinks at 6pm, and talks will kickoff at 6:30pm. There'll also be pizza, and when the talks finish up (around 7:30pm) there'll be more time for drinks and networking. Look forward to seeing you then!﻿

name: GDG Melbourne - September -  Android DataBinding & Android Vector Assets
description:
Welcome to Google Developers Melbourne, September Meetup. 

This month our meetup is one week earlier than usual.  This is to allow some of the presenters at this months Yow Connected conference to beta test their presentations!

We also have a Special session to discuss the future direction of GDG Melbourne.


Build Better Android Apps with Vector Assets
Luke Sleeman

There are many advantages to using vector-based assets in your Android apps — smaller binary size, faster loading, easier support for all pixel densities, dynamic drawing, and more ways to animate. Despite the upsides, SVGs and VectorDrawable assets are more complex to author and use.

Luke explores everything needed to implement SVGs and VectorDrawables on Android, including common issues and their remedies. 

Android DataBinding: This is the DSL You're Looking For!
Maksim Lin

The Android Data Binding Library is great for reducing the amount of boiler plate you need to build the view layer in your android apps.

But going beyond the basics will give you an even bigger payback.

In this talk I'll cover some of the more advanced users of Data Binding including:

• 2-way Data Binding

• custom attributes 

• complex widgets

• integrating 3rd party libraries

As a bonus, examples will come from an app in development for several year, in Google Play with thousands of users that has been refactored recently to use Data Binding.

For those that have seen the Google IO talk "Advanced Data Binding" this talk will serve as a good followup, providing more real-world examples of how to use Data Binding in your app and covering areas like 3rd party libraries that were not covered in the IO talk and are not well documented outside of blog posts and SO answers.

Community discussion around GDG's future.

Shine have told us that from next year they will no longer be able to provide us with a venue, or sponsor us for drinks and pizza.  This is so they can focus on the GDG Cloud meetup.  Shine have been a major supporter of GDG for years, and we are very grateful for their support.

The GDG Cloud Meetup and Shine ending their sponsorship have prompted some big questions about what GDG should be.  We used to be the "Android Melbourne" meetup.  The entire reason we became a GDG is to get more support off Google.  However becoming a GDG has come with a huge cost and caused some pretty big issues in how we market ourselves and how we are perceived.  Some questions up for discussion are:

• Do we remain a GDG, or do we go back to just being an Android meetup?

• If we do remain a GDG, what do we cover apart from Android?

• How are we going to find Volunteers, a venue and sponsors?

• What sort of events should we be running?  A monthly meetup?  Hack nights?  Conferences?  Drinks at the pub?

We will be hosting a community discussion to try and find answers to these questions, and to decide how we will deal with losing Shine as our major sponsor next year.

Lastly, to be very clear:  NONE OF THIS HAS ANY IMPACT ON THE DEVFEST!  It is going ahead as planned and it's looking like it will be a great event.  There will also be no changes in Shines commitment to GDG Melbourne until next year, so the November and December meetups will run as usual.

15% off offer on Yow Connected Kotlin workshop

Are you a Java developer interested in learning Kotlin?  Yow Connected have offered GDG attendees 15% off on their 1 day workshop:  Kotlin for Java Developers which is running on Wednesday the 20th of September.  The workshop will be facilitated by Svetlana Isakova, who is a Developer Advocate at JetBrains, Core Developer of the Kotlin language and co-author of the book Kotlin in Action.

Simply use the code GDGMELB-15 when purchasing your tickets.

Schedule

Doors open for drinks at 6pm, and talks will kickoff at 6:30pm. There'll also be pizza, and when the talks finish up (around 8:00pm) there'll be more time for drinks and networking. Look forward to seeing you then!﻿

name: GDG DevFest Melbourne 2017
description:
The DevFest is a ticketed event. All attendees must purchase tickets from eventbrite.

Dev Fests are the largest community-run Google related events in the world! Dev Fest Melbourne is a conference for developers, run by developers bringing together world class experts in Android, Web and Cloud technologies. Our DevFest is carefully crafted for you by the local Melbourne GDG community. There will be awesome speakers, great topics, and lots fun! DevFest will, at its core, be powered by a shared belief that when developers come together to exchange ideas, amazing things can happen!

This day long conference will feature world class speakers:

• 4 Googlers: Scott Thomson, Adam Koch, KJ Pittl and Mark Mandel

• 4 Google developer experts, including Andrew Kelly, Zarah Dominguez and Wilson Mendes from Sydney as well as local Cloud GDE Graham Polley

• Many other great speakers, like Kris Howard, Kruti Patel, Gareth Jones, Lucas Richards, Gareth Jones, Mark Ng, Kruti Garga, Mark Bergin, Drew Pearse, Michelle Gleeson, James Percy and Darren Kong

Great presentations on subjects like:

• Building for the google assistant

• Android Architecture Components

• Scalable real time microservices

• Android databinding

• Training image classifiers

• Constraint Layout on Android

• Googles Awareness API

• Chatbots and Natural Language Processing

• VR

Buy your ticket now!

Early bird tickets get a free DevFest T-shirt!

Order your ticket before October the 9th to receive a free DevFest T-shirt when you attend!  you will be asked for your T-shirt size, etc once you purchase your ticket.

For the full program and speakers lineup stay tuned to http://gdgmelbourne.com/ and follow @GDGMelbourne on Twitter

name: Melbourne Android - November - Augmented Reality, Apps for Live Events & Kotlin
description:
Welcome to Melbourne Android's, November Meetup.

This month we have googler James Birney flying in from Sydney to speak about Augmented Reality and ARCore!  We also have a case study on building apps for live sporting events @ IBM and a talk about Kotline read only collections.


Lightning Talks:

Supporting Android Apps for Live Sporting Events - Katie, IBM.

Write better code with Kotlin's read only collections - Elisha

Main talk

ARCore introduction, demos and how to get started - James Birney, Google
Augmented reality has taken a great leaps forward recently with both Google and Apple releasing new SDKs.  Developers can now easily blend together the virtual and physical worlds.  James Birnely from Google will be introducing ARCore and demonstrating how you can use it to build AR apps.  This will include an introduction to some of the key concepts behind AR and demos of the great things you build with AR.  We will also see how developers can get started developing with ARCore.

Door prizes

We have some Yow Connected T-shirts to give away!  Winners will be drawn at the end of the night

Schedule

Doors open for drinks at 6pm, and talks will kickoff at 6:30pm. There'll also be pizza, and when the talks finish up (around 7:30pm) there'll be more time for drinks and networking. We look forward to seeing you then!﻿

name: Xmas party CocoaHeads, Android GDG & Melbourne Mobile
description:
Melbourne's 3 mobile meet-ups:  Cocaheads, Android GDG and Melbourne Mobile will be getting together for a combined Christmas party!  There’ll be food, drinks, talks, fun activities and give-aways! 

There are a limited number of places available, so you must sign up for a ticket via eventbrite

Talks:

LJ Kenward will be bringing us an important Christmas message, on The Value of Junior Developers, and the common problems they face when joining teams!  This is a particularly important issue for Mobile, with the mobile space continuing to grow and many companies around Melbourne are struggling to fill roles.

LJ Kenward runs the Junior Dev meetups in Melbourne and Perth, helps with lots more, and has a burgeoning speaking career.

Activities

Once again we will be doing awful startup pitches!  “Uber for clowns”, “Cloud services for toddlers”, “Twitter for dogs” - We will be putting together elevator pitches for some truly terrible startup ideas.  Teams will be formed on the night and you will get to pick a ‘terrible startup idea’ out of a hat.  Each team will have 10 minutes to put together an elevator pitch for their startup.  Prizes will be awarded for ‘worst startup idea’ and ‘most likely to already exist’.

Prizes:

Slack socks -  Thanks to Slack, We have 8 pairs of slack socks, which will be stuffed with Christmas goodies. 

Reveal License - Itty Bitty Apps have kindly donated a License for Reveal.  Reveal brings powerful runtime view debugging to iOS developers.  All christmas party attendees will also be given a 15% discount when purchasing Reveal.

JetBrains License - JetBrains have also donated two 1 year individual subscriptions, which can be used with any of their IDE's (eg, IntelliJ IDEA, AppCode, etc).

Schedule & Location

The Christmas party will be hosted at Shine Solutions - Level 30, 600 Bourke St, Melbourne. Doors open for drinks and pizza at 6pm

name: Melbourne Android January - Transitions, Constraint layout and more!
description:
Welcome to Melbourne Androids, January Meetup.
This month we have talks on Transitions without Activities or Fragments. A talk for beginners on Constraint Layout and more!

We are starting off the new year, with a new location! This will be our first meeting at our new host - WeWork. We are also going to be doing Dry January - so there will be juice and soft drinks, but no alcohol.

Lightning Talks:

Mark Hollands - Beginning Constraint Layout
Zubin Pratap - Firebase at Whooshka

Main talk:
Chris Horner - Transitions without Activities or Fragments

Android's Transition framework is extremely powerful, but almost all examples involve the use of Activities and Fragments. In a world where many developers are now foregoing Fragments, this talk aims to provide some solid examples and strategies on how to use Transitions without them.

Chris has given this presentation at droidcon SF - we are very lucky to have him presenting locally!

Schedule
Doors open for drinks at 6pm, and talks will kickoff at 6:30pm. There'll also be pizza, and when the talks finish up (around 7:30pm) there'll be more time for drinks and networking. We look forward to seeing you then!

All attendees agree to follow Google Event Community Guidelines and Anti-Harassment Policy - https://www.google.com/events/policy/anti-harassmentpolicy.html
how_to_find_us: A GDG Organiser will be at the front of the building to swipe you into the elevators.  Please go to Level 4

name: Melbourne Android February - Android Things - A beginners Guide
description:
Welcome to Melbourne Androids, February Meetup.
This month we have an exciting meetup - GDE Andrew Kelly will be flying in from Sydney to give an beginners introduction to "Android Things" - googles Android based IoT solution. We also have Mark Ng talking about the Android phone API and David Kennedy giving an introduction to material design!

Lightning Talks:

Mark Ng - Phone API
David Kennedy (@davkenn) - Beginning Material Design

Main talk:
Andrew Kelly (@andrew_ke11y) - "Android Things - A beginners Guide"
Google Developer Expert Andrew Kelly, will cover what Android Things is, and how to create your first project linking an IoT device running Android Things to Firebase. We will see a practical example of connecting temperature sensors, LEDs and switches to an Android Things device and controlling these peripherals using Android code. Andrew will be giving the same talk that wowed the crowds at Sydneys 2017 DevFest!

Schedule
Doors open for drinks at 6pm, and talks will kickoff at 6:30pm. There'll also be pizza, and when the talks finish up (around 7:30pm) there'll be more time for drinks and networking. We look forward to seeing you then!

There will be an Outware employee downstairs to let people in. Take the elevator to level 3. Doors close at 6:30 sharp!

name: Melbourne Android March - Android TV, Chrome OS containers and Android CI
description:
Welcome to Melbourne Android's March Meetup.

This month our main talk will be on Android TV and the Leanback Library. We will have lighting talks on Chrome OS containers, and Beginning Android CI.

Lightning Talks:

Patrick Yin (@patrickrayyin) - Beginning Android CI
Maksim Lin (@mklin) - Chrome OS Containers

Main talk:
Kruti Patel (@krutimevada) & Billy Chang (@billychang) - Designing Android TV apps using the Leanback library

It is very rare that you get to work on Android TV app and when you do, first thing Google suggests is to use Leanback Library. We have been building TV app using Leanback and its has some huge positives but also some limitations. We will share our knowledge about how to design and develop tv apps using Leanback library along with some tips and tricks.

Door prize:
We have 2 free tickets to the Voxxed Days conference ( https://voxxeddays.com/melbourne/ ) to give away! In addition all attendees will receive a discount code for Voxxed Days tickets!

Schedule
Doors open for drinks at 6pm, and talks will kickoff at 6:30pm. There'll also be pizza, and when the talks finish up (around 7:30pm) there'll be more time for drinks and networking. We look forward to seeing you then!

name: Melbourne Android - AI on Mobile, Crashlytics and Google IO
description:
Welcome to Melbourne Android's April Meetup.

This month our main talk will be on Deep Learning on Mobile and Edge Devices. We will have lighting talks on the upcoming Google IO, and Beginning Crashlytics.

Lightning Talks:

Katie B (@KatieBarnett_5) - Beginning Crashlytics
Mike hughes (@mikehughestweet) - Google IO Preview

Main talk:
Daniel Bradby (@dbradby) - Deep Learning on Mobile and Edge Devices

Mobile and AI are a natural fit. We will look at the current state of deep learning on mobile and edge devices. This will include using hardware acceleration with GPUs and DSPs, as well as the specialised Movidius VPU. We will also review software such as TensorFlow Lite and Android's Neural Network API. Finally we examine some deep learning models available and how they can be customised and optimised for running predictions on small devices.

Schedule
Doors open for drinks at 6pm, and talks will kickoff at 6:30pm. There'll also be pizza, and when the talks finish up (around 7:30pm) there'll be more time for drinks and networking. We look forward to seeing you then!

name: I/O Extended Meetup Melbourne
description:
GDG Melbourne will be hosting an I/O Extended event to recap all of the major announcements from Google I/O and talk about what's new in the Google world. I/O is Google's annual developer conference, where new products and API’s are announced and technology showcased. I/O also features a large number of technical in sessions focused on building products with Google's technologies such as Android, Flutter, Assistant, AR Core, Google Cloud and Tensorflow.

I/O can be a busy time with a bewildering array of product announcements, new technologies and updates to make sense of. GDG Melbourne will bring together expert developers to help you cut through the hype and understand what's important and what's not.

Presentations:
The IO Experience - Katie ( @KatieBarnett_5 )
What’s new: Assistant - Hong Yew
What’s new: Android - Andrew Kelly (Google Developer Expert - @andrew_ke11y)
What’s new: AI/ML & Whats new: AR - Daniel Bradby ( @dbradby )
What’s new: Flutter.io - Craig Edwards ( @edwardaux )

Door prizes:
1 AIY Vision Kit from Google!
1 AIY Voice Kit from Google!
4 I/O 18 Android figurines

Swag for tweets - Tweet @gdgmelbourne #io18extended on the night, to take a lucky dip from the GDG Swag bag!

T-Shirts:
I/O Extended 2018 T-shirts will be available on a first come/first served basis. They are sure to be popular, so arrive early to secure your size!

Doors open for drinks and pizza at 5:30pm, and talks will kickoff at 6:00. Talks will run through to 8:00, followed by more time for drinks, networking and discussion. We must leave the venue by 9:00

All attendees are asked to act in accordance with our Code of Conduct ( https://goo.gl/SBGSou )

name: GDG Planning Session
description:
This session is to help plan out our activities for the next 12 months of GDG. If you are interested in volunteering with the Melbourne GDG, this is a great opportunity to get onboard!

Coming out of I/O we have a bunch of new people who are interested in helping out, as well as plenty of ideas for new things GDG could do: different formats for the meetups, code labs, surveys our members, connect with other groups, etc!

I want to go through all the possible things that we could be doing, prioritise them, and see who is interested in doing what. This should be a good opportunity to shuffle around responsibility between some of the more experienced volunteers, as well as divide up some tasks for those who have just joined us, or who are interested in helping out.

description:

Tim Wakulicz will be following up on one of the most interesting I/O announcements giving a lightning talk on Beginning the Navigation Library. We also have Renaud Lienhart giving a lightning talk on what was announced at WWDC! Renaud previously worked for Apple in California so it will be great to get some analysis from a true apple expert!

Lightning Talks:

Tim Wakulicz (@timatoe) - Beginning Navigation Library
Renaud Lienhart (@layoutSubviews) - Tales from the Other Side - Whats new from WWDC

Main talk:
Chris Horner (@chris_h_codes) - Conductor: A discussion of architecture and alternatives

name: DevFest 2018
description:
IMPORTANT - The DevFest 2018 is a TICKETED event.

Please buy your tickets from - https://www.eventbrite.com.au/e/gdg-devfest-melbourne-2018-tickets-48116122618

This year we are running a bigger event with 300 general attendees. All attendees must purchase tickets from Eventbrite. Last year, tickets SOLD OUT in under 3 weeks so you must be quick. DevFest 2018 tickets will go on sale mid-August 2018 so please add this date to your calendar.

This year DevFest is organized by three awesome meetups; GDG Melbourne, Melbourne Tensorflow and Angular Melbourne. Dev Fests are the largest community-run Google related events in the world! Dev Fest Melbourne is a conference for developers, run by developers bringing together world-class experts in Android, Web and Cloud technologies. Our DevFest is carefully crafted for you by the local Melbourne GDG community. There will be awesome speakers, great topics, and lots of fun! DevFest will, at its core, be powered by a shared belief that when developers come together to exchange ideas, amazing things can happen!

For the full program and speakers lineup stay tuned to https://www.gdgmelbourne.com/devfest-2018/ and follow @GDGMelbourne on Twitter (https://twitter.com/GDGMelbourne)

name: Flutter Study Jam part 1 of 3
description:
Flutter is Google’s mobile app SDK for crafting high-quality native interfaces on Android and iOS in record time. Flutter works with existing code, is used by developers and organisations around the world, and is free and open source.

Want to get started on building Flutter apps?

Join us for our Flutter Study Jam! Together we'll work through the Flutter Udacity Course prepared by Google instructors. You will be able to get hands-on experience with Flutter and build a Flutter app while learning the fundamentals..

Bring a laptop! The course will run on all of the latest versions of the popular browsers. For the best experience, the laptop should have Flutter installed on it prior to starting the study jam to save time. Windows/Linux/Mac would all be fine. Check out : https://flutter.io/get-started/install/

name: November Meetup - Google Melbourne Office
description:
Welcome to Melbourne Android's November Meetup.

Topics for the night will be:
- Kotlin vs Java Lighting talk (Suesi Tran)
- Smart Actions for Google Home Lighting talk (Carl Hickton @CarlHickton)
- Integrating your IOT devices using Home Assistant with Google Assistant (Sebastian Doan and Nathan Borysiewicz @sebastian_doan)

Sebastian and Nathan promise some amazing demos! They have provided the following talk description:

The Google Assistant currently supports integration with thousand of Smart Home Devices. That's great from an end consumer perspective, however what if you wanted to integrate your own non-supported devices? And what if the existing integrations don't meet your needs or use-cases? Using Home Assistant, an open source platform, you can integrate, monitor, control and automate all of your IP connected devices. It can also be integrated to the Google Assistant and act as a bridge to all of your devices.

Sebastian Doan and Nathan Borysiewicz, will walk through the high level capabilities of Home assistant and demonstrate how it can integrate with Google for voice based control, casting cameras and TTS notifications. We'll also provide a demonstration of numerous connected devices (lights, vacuum, presence sensors and heating/cooling) and give an overview how we use Home assistant to manage our smart homes.

Schedule
Doors open for drinks just before 6pm, and talks will kickoff at 6:30pm. There’ll also be pizza and when the talks finish up there’ll be more time for drinks and networking. We will head off for after event drinks at 8:30

The venue has limited capacity

name: Xmas party CocoaHeads, Android GDG & Melbourne Mobile
description:
Melbourne's 3 mobile meet-ups: CocoaHeads, Android GDG and Melbourne Mobile will be getting together for a combined Christmas party! There’ll be food, drinks, fun activities and give-aways!

Talks:

An Ode to the Hacker - Ayesha Ahmed (@tesseract_256)
What happens when you combine abstract ideas with the power of technology? From building vehicles out of shopping carts to playing tetris on a building, hackers bring novelty in unexpected ways. Join us in this talk bringing together the history of hacker culture and the hacker ethic, and how they cross both economic and cultural barriers.

Activities:

Once again we will be doing awful startup pitches! “Uber for clowns”, “Cloud services for toddlers”, “Twitter for dogs” - We will be putting together elevator pitches for some truly terrible startup ideas. Teams will be formed on the night and you will get to pick a ‘terrible startup idea’ out of a hat. Each team will have 10 minutes to put together an elevator pitch for their startup. Prizes will be awarded for ‘worst startup idea’

Prizes:

Apple TV - Provided by CocoaHeads

Google branded swag and Mini Android Figures - Provided by GDG

2 Reveal Licenses - Provided by IttyBittyApps

WTM bags - We have 10 Women Techmakers bags which will be stuffed with Christmas goodies.

Schedule & Location

The Christmas party will be hosted on the 1st floor, YBF Ventures, 520 Bourke Street, Melbourne. Doors open for drinks and pizza at 6pm
